Found Management System Revisions Version Primary Author(s) Description of Version Date Completed 1.0 K Asritha Disha Initial Complete Draft 06/08/2025 Software Requirements Specification for Lost and Found Management System Page 1 1 Introduction 1.1 Document Purpose This Software Requirements Specification (SRS) document defines the functional and non- functional requirements for the Lost and Found Management System (LFMS), version 1.0. The system is designed to streamline the process of reporting, searching, and managing lost or found items within a college campus. The purpose is to provide a clear and unambiguous description of system requirements to guide developers, testers, and stakeholders in creating a reliable application for campus use. 1.2 Product Scope The LFMS provides a centralized platform for students, staff, and faculty to report lost or found belongings. Users can submit item details, upload images, and browse/search reports to find matches. Administrators validate entries and assist in resolving claims. Key benefits: • Reduces manual overhead in lost-and-found processes. • Provides faster matching of lost and found items. • Increases accountability and transparency. • Offers a secure and searchable digital repository. . 1.3 Intended Audience and Document Overview • Intended audience: • Developers: to design and build the system. • Testers: to validate system performance. • Students/Staff: as primary users. • College administration: as system overseers. • Instructors: as academic evaluators. • Document overview: • Section 1: Introduction and background. • Section 2: Overall system description. • Section 3: Specific requirements (functional + interface). • Section 4: Non-functional requirements. • Section 5: Other requirements. • Appendices: Data dictionary and group activity log. Software Requirements Specification for Lost and Found Management System Page 2 1.4 Definitions, Acronyms and Abbreviations Term / Acronym Definition AI Artificial Intelligence LFMS Lost and Found Management System DB Database SRS

• Section 4: Non-functional requirements. • Section 5: Other requirements. • Appendices: Data dictionary and group activity log. Software Requirements Specification for Lost and Found Management System Page 2 1.4 Definitions, Acronyms and Abbreviations Term / Acronym Definition AI Artificial Intelligence LFMS Lost and Found Management System DB Database SRS Software Requirements Specification ML Machine Learning JWT Jsonwebtoken(for authentication) 1.5 Document Conventions This document follows the IEEE formatting standards for SRS documents. The text is written in Times New Roman font, size 12, single-spaced, with 1-inch margins. Section and subsection headings are bolded and numbered as per the template. Italics are used to denote comments or instructions throughout the document. Technical terms are capitalized consistently, and acronyms are defined upon first use. 1.6 References and Acknowledgments IEEE Standard 830-1998, IEEE Recommended Practice for SRS. Articles on Campus IT Solutions and Digital Lost & Found Systems. Discussions with faculty and college administrative staff. Special thanks to Dr Anila M for continuous guidance. Software Requirements Specification for Lost and Found Management System Page 3 2 Overall Description 2.1 Product Overview The LFMS is a web-based application that connects users who lose items with those who find them. Flow: [User Reports Lost Item] → [Database] → [Search & Match Engine] → [User Notifications + Admin Validation] It integrates with existing campus systems (such as student login portals) and is accessible through browsers and mobile devices. 2.2 Product Functionality The following is a high-level summary of major functions the system must perform: Allow users to report lost/found items with descriptions and images. Enable users to search/filter items by category, date, or location. Provide matching suggestions between lost and found items. Maintain a secure repository of reports. Allow admin validation and approval of entries. Generate claim reports for returned items. 2.3 Design and Implementation Constraints Web-based system using React (Frontend), Node.js/Express (Backend), MongoDB (Database). Must comply with basic data privacy rules. Accessible on desktop and mobile browsers. Reports must be generated within 2 seconds. Must use role-based access control (Admin vs User). 2.4 Assumptions and Dependencies The following assumptions and dependencies may affect the final implementation of the system: • Users have internet access. • All entries depend on truthful reporting by users. • Campus email authentication will be used for verification. • The accuracy of search depends on the quality of submitted details. • Some components will reuse modules from existing projects Software Requirements Specification for Lost and Found Management System Page 4 3 Specific Requirements 3.1 External Interface Requirements 3.1.1 User Interfaces Simple web interface with login, report submission, and search dashboard. Image upload option for item identification. Admin dashboard for verifying claims. 3.1.2 Hardware Interfaces Runs on desktops, laptops, and smartphones. Works with standard web browsers. 3.1.3 Software Interfaces Campus login APIs for authentication. MongoDB database. Email/SMS service for notifications. 3.2 Functional Requirements F1: The system shall allow users to register/login using campus credentials. F2: The system shall allow users to report lost or found items. F3: The system shall provide search

with standard web browsers. 3.1.3 Software Interfaces Campus login APIs for authentication. MongoDB database. Email/SMS service for notifications. 3.2 Functional Requirements F1: The system shall allow users to register/login using campus credentials. F2: The system shall allow users to report lost or found items. F3: The system shall provide search and filter features for items. F4: The system shall suggest possible matches between lost and found reports. F5: The system shall allow admins to verify, approve, or delete reports. F6: The system shall notify users via email when a potential match is found. F7: The system shall generate a claim/return report when an item is resolved. 3.3 Use Case Model 3.3.1 Use Case #1 (Report Lost Item) Author – Asritha Purpose - User submits details of a lost item for storage and future matching. Requirements Traceability – F2, F4 Software Requirements Specification for Lost and Found Management System Page 5 Priority - High Preconditions – User logged in Post conditions – Item stored in database Actors – User, System, Admin. Extends – If this is an extension use case, identify which use case(s) it extends Flow of Events • User selects “Report Lost Item.” • Fills details (category, description, location, image). • System saves data. • Admin reviews and approves. • Alternative Flow: If details incomplete, system prompts correction. 3.3.2 Use Case #2(Report Found Item) (similar to the above with Found item details) 3.3.3 Use Case #3(Search & Match Items) Author – Asritha Purpose – User searches the system for lost or found items and system attempts to match similar records. Requirements Traceability – F3, F5 Priority – High Preconditions – User is logged in; system has stored lost/found items. Post conditions – Matching results are displayed to the user; user may contact item owner/finder. Actors – User, System, Admin. Extends – Extends Report Lost Item and Report Found Item (since it depends on stored items). Flow of Events • User selects “Search Items.” • User enters filters (category, date, location, keywords). • System retrieves and displays matching items. • If a potential match is found, user views details. • Admin may verify before allowing contact details exchange. Alternative Flow • If no match found, system suggests creating a new lost/found report. • If insufficient filters provided, system prompts for more details. Software Requirements Specification for Lost and Found Management System Page 6 4 Other Non-functional Requirements 4.1 Performance Requirements P1: Diagnosis (match search) within 3 seconds.. P2: The system shall handle up to 100 users at the same time without slowing down. 4.2 Safety and Security Requirements S1: Passwords encrypted using hashing. S2: Only authenticated users can post items. S3: Admin verification prevents misuse. S4: Users must log in using a secure username and password. S5: Mobile access must use SSL/TLS for secure communication. 4.3 Software Quality Attributes 4.3.1 Reliability Data should not be lost during posting/claiming. 4.3.2 Adaptability Simple, intuitive UI for non-technical users. Software Requirements Specification for Lost and Found Management System Page 7 Appendix A –

using a secure username and password. S5: Mobile access must use SSL/TLS for secure communication. 4.3 Software Quality Attributes 4.3.1 Reliability Data should not be lost during posting/claiming. 4.3.2 Adaptability Simple, intuitive UI for non-technical users. Software Requirements Specification for Lost and Found Management System Page 7 Appendix A – Data Dictionary Name Type Category Description Example Item_id String Identifier Unique ID for each reported item ITM1029 Item_type String Input Type of item (lost/found) lost description String Input Description of the item Black wallet location String Input Location where item lost/found Library date_reported Date Input Date when item was reported 2025-08-05 status String State Var Current state of item (pending, claimed) Claimed user_id String Identifier User who submitted the report Cnyue4f74 image_url String Input Image of the item link.jpg Software Requirements Specification for Lost and Found Management System Page 8 Appendix B - Group Log Date Members Present Activity Description 23 July Asritha Collected requirements for LFMS 24 July Disha Researched campus lost & found systems 26 July Asritha Designed backend data models 28 July Disha Worked on frontend wireframes 30 July Both Integrated draft UI + DB 31 July Both Wrote & finalized SRS document
